page.title:
Data Conversion Process Flow
Data Conversion Process Flow
page.normal_text:
Project Start Up Flow involve: Kickoff meeting then Review scope then start data conversion plan then identify project team then project plan review and sign off. Project Start up leads into design. Source Data/Document Review
Project Start Up Flow involve: Kickoff meeting then Review scope then start data conversion plan then identify project team then project plan
review and sign off. Project Start up leads into design.
Source
Data/Document
Review

Develop Analysis Dataset Specs Design flow involves: Source data/document review then issue identification and resolution then mapping spec development then spec QC then spec review and sign off. Design leads into data conversion.
Develop Analysis
Dataset Specs
Design flow involves: Source data/document review then issue identification and resolution then mapping spec development then spec QC
then spec review and sign off. Design leads into data conversion.

Data Conversion flow involves: Create database structure then convert source data to SDTM then domain QC and compliance checks then Convert Source create pool then comain review and sign off. Data conversion leads into publishing. Data to SDTM
Data Conversion flow involves: Create database structure then convert source data to SDTM then domain QC and compliance checks then
Convert Source
create pool then comain review and sign off. Data conversion leads into publishing.
Data to SDTM

Publishing flow involves: Create annotated CRF then create DDT and hyperlink to a CRF then QC bookmark and DDT then publishing review and sign off. Publishing leads into AdaM.
Publishing flow involves: Create annotated CRF then create DDT and hyperlink to a CRF then QC bookmark and DDT then publishing review
and sign off. Publishing leads into AdaM.

Domain QC & Adam flow involves: Develop analysis dataset specs then develop SAS programs then create Adam datasets from SDTM then Asam validation Compliance Checks then Dataset review and sign off. This concludes the Data Conversion process flow
Domain QC &
Adam flow involves: Develop analysis dataset specs then develop SAS programs then create Adam datasets from SDTM then Asam validation
Compliance Checks
then Dataset review and sign off. This concludes the Data Conversion process flow

page.title:
Modern Analytical Tools
Modern Analytical Tools

Objectives of Modern Analytical Tools
Objectives of Modern Analytical Tools

picture.name: Image6
picture.caption: • Provide research computing infrastructure (hardware, software, support staff) needed for scientists to conduct comparative effectiveness research on behalf of the FDA.

page.enlisting:
– Reason for FDA’s participation in ARRA CER and for it’s inclusion of a task for implementing modern analytical tools was to jump start FDA’s technical infrastructure for scientific research computing. – For CER, could use what FDA already has but would miss the opportunity • Data should be stored consistent with the envisioned data marts that • Modern analytical software should be configured to take advantage of • Network accessible from either regulatory or scientific network and with – Reason for FDA’s participation in ARRA CER and for it’s inclusion of a task for implementing modern analytical tools was to jump start FDA’s technical infrastructure for scientific research computing.

page.title:
CER Study 2: Systematic Assessment of the Benefits and Risks of a therapy (TBD): A Multicriteria Decision Analysis using the Analytic Hierarchy Process
CER Study 2: Systematic Assessment of the Benefits and Risks of a
therapy (TBD): A Multicriteria Decision Analysis using the Analytic
Hierarchy Process
page.normal_text:
Specific Aim: To conduct a multi-criteria decision analysis to do a benefit-risk assessment of the thiazolidinediones in individuals with type 2 diabetes relative to sulfonylureas and metformin, using the Analytic Hierarchy Process. (Dolan, 1989; Tsaty, 1994; Singh, 2006; Dolan, 2008)
Specific Aim:
To conduct a multi-criteria decision analysis to do a benefit-risk assessment of T o
c o n d u c t
a
m u l t i - c r i t e r i a
d e c i s i o n
a n a l y s i s t o
d o
a
b e n e f i t - r i s k
a s s e s s m e n t
o f
the thiazolidinediones in individuals with type 2 diabetes relative to sulfonylureas
and metformin, using the Analytic Hierarchy Process. (Dolan, 1989; Tsaty, 1994;
Singh, 2006; Dolan, 2008)

The Analytic Hierarchy process can flexibly address a range of decisions that involve both quantitative data and subjective input. The methodology can also be applied to evaluate medications in the pre-approval period, with appropriate accounting for uncertainty around the estimates of long term safety. Investigators will: define the decision context; assemble and organize outcome information; make comparisons among the alternatives; combine the results of the judgments; and perform sensitivity analyses.

information; make comparisons among the alternatives; combine the results of the
judgments; and perform sensitivity analyses.

page.title:
Clinical Design Strategy 1: Optimal Clinical Trial Designs for Estimating Treatment Effects in Subpopulations
Clinical Design Strategy 1: Optimal Clinical Trial Designs for
Estimating Treatment Effects in Subpopulations
page.normal_text:
Will consider three categories of studies: 1) where the subpopulations of interest are known before the study starts, and there are relatively few; 2) where the subpopulations of interest are known before the study starts, and there are more than a few such subpopulations of interest; and 3) where the subpopulations of interest are unknown before the study starts.

Will construct candidate clinical trial designs aimed at making inferences about specific subpopulations. Will include group sequential designs with no adaptation, and group sequential designs that incorporate the following types of pre-specified adaptations at interim analyses: changes in the sample size, changes in the randomization probabilities, and changes in the subpopulations sampled.

picture.name: Image6
picture.caption: Specific Aim: To develop statistical methods and software that will enable investigators and regulators to determine, for a given scenario, the best trial designs and analyses for generating evidence about treatment effectiveness in different subpopulations.

page.title:
Clinical Design Strategy 2: Improved Design of Randomized Trials with Use of Information from Historical Controls
Clinical Design Strategy 2: Improved Design of
Randomized Trials with Use of Information from
Historical Controls
page.normal_text:
Flexible Bayesian nonparametric models allows one to include more relevant data sources than is possible when using other models; the mixture approach will be more robust to data-source-specific departures from a common, exchangeable hierarchical model.
Flexible Bayesian nonparametric models allows one to include more
relevant data sources than is possible when using other models; the
mixture approach will be more robust to data-source-specific
departures from a common, exchangeable hierarchical model.

We will develop and test this model, using the RCTs in JANUS and data from other databases. We will carry out simulation studies to test these mixture prior models and compare the method to alternative formulations for incorporating historical data. We will use patient-level data in FDA database, along with complementary data warehoused in these other databases.

picture.caption: Specific Aim: To develop mixture prior models for use when incorporating historical control data with a concurrent control that is part of a randomized controlled trial (RCT).
